Thanks for reporting the issue. Are you working on a fix, too? We cannot just merge a test that fails -- and thus breaks the build :) Nevertheless, your test is useful. Maybe we can `@ignore` the test and merge (if you don't work a a fix) for now.
\cc @guozhangwang

A global store can't be logged. It is maintained from a topic. It doesn't need a changelog. Perhaps we should check the store supplier doesn't have logging enabled?

Did not look into the issue in detail. If you are sure this fixed the problem, I am fine with that. We can through an informative exception for user stores with changelog enabled. Or maybe, just disable it internally?

I am wondering, if `builder.table()` is affected here, too. It would also not need changelog enabled.

@guozhangwang we wrap exceptions as streams exceptions since the code that calls these functions and retries only understands streams exceptions. I'd argue that's a good thing since that code cannot possibly know all other exceptions in the lower layers.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed):

Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

@guozhangwang about  `I still think it's better to fail fast and educate users retry creating their apps after the broker is fully up than trying to wait for, say 5 seconds and hopefully it will succeed.` Remember that the broker can fail anytime and the user cannot have any guarantee that once a broker is up it won't fail again. In a subsequent JIRA we can consider unifying the backoff times to match other standard backoff times that clients use.
Discussed offline with @ijuma, but we might await KIP-101 to avoid introducing more opportunities for transient failures.

@junrao As of current patch the logStartOffset of compacted topic is always 0. It seems reasonable because if consumer seek to offset 0 of a compacted topic, they will still be able to consume (instead of receiving OffsetOutofRangeException) even if the offset of the first message is larger than 0. And it is not straightforward to retrieve the offset of the first message in the segment. According to Java doc, `RecordBatch.baseOffset()` will `return the first offset of the original record batch for magic version prior to 2`, which means the baseOffset of the first batch of the first log segment doesn't necessarily tell us the offset of the first message in the log. Does this sound reasonable?

Passing tests here: http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2017-03-27--001.1490660144--hachikuji--add-replication-testcase-for-compression--40f1c37/report.txt.

I found the reason why the new integration test was failing. With a recent refactor of `Sender.completeBatch`, we only requested a metadata update on non-retriable errors. This was a regression, and as a result, when the leader for a partition changed, the metadata would not get updated and all the retries would get exhausted.

I moved the metadata update code to the correct place, and the tests are passing now. I also addressed other PR comments. cc @junrao
Somehow the new integration test only failed with JDK7 or scala 2.12, neither of which I run locally. So I never caught it until this PR.

@hachikuji Could you help review this PR? Thanks

@simplesteph Good catch, fix makes sense given the call to `commitOffsets` in there.

It seems that this was introduced as a regression in `KAFKA-4161: KIP-89: Allow sink connectors to decouple flush and offset commit`. Perhaps there is a unit test in `WorkerSinkTaskTest` that could catch such a regression?

@mjsax `builder.table()` will be fine as it constructs the `StateStore`. The issue here is that the `StateStore` is constructed externally. Also, there is no way of telling from the `StateStore` if it has logging enabled or not. We could change the `StateStore` param to be a `StateStoreSupplier` so that we can check for `loggingEnabled`. That is going to require a KIP, though
I am not sure why the previous code was hard to read? Both variants mean the same thing. The fact that the internal state involves two fields should be an implementation detail.
